problem: Find the cross product of $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}.$
solution:
The cross product of $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}$ is
\[\begin{pmatrix} (-1)(-5) - (4)(2) \\ (2)(3) - (-5)(1) \\ (1)(4) - (3)(-1) \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ 11 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
model_solution:
Step 1: The cross product of two vectors $\mathbf{a}=\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\ a_2 \\ a_3 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\mathbf{b}=\begin{pmatrix} b_1 \\ b_2 \\ b_3 \end{pmatrix}$ is given by the vector $\begin{pmatrix} a_2 b_3-a_3 b_2 \\ a_3 b_1-a_1 b_3 \\ a_1 b_2-a_2 b_1 \end{pmatrix}$
$\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}\times\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} (-1)(-5)-2(4) \\ 2(3)-1(-5) \\ 1(4)-(-1)(3) \end{pmatrix}$
Step 2: $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}\times\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} (-1)(-5)-2(4) \\ 2(3)-1(-5) \\ 1(4)-(-1)(3) \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} -5-8 \\ 6+5 \\ 4+3 \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} -13 \\ 11 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$
$\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}\times\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} -13 \\ 11 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$
Step 3: $\begin{pmatrix} -13 \\ 11 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$
Step 4: $\begin{pmatrix} -13 \\ 11 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$
Step 5: $\begin{pmatrix} -13 \\ 11 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$
Step 6: $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -13 \\ 11 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}$
Step 7: $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -13 \\ 11 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}$
Step 2: $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}\times\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} (-1)(-5)-2(4) \\ 2(3)-1(-5) \\ 1(4)-(-1)(3) \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} -5-8 \\ 6+5 \\ 4+3 \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} -13 \\ 11 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$
